February 5, 2006: Fiction
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A murder at the
Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to the discovery
of a secret society.
THE HOSTAGE, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $26.95.) An Army officer probes the
murder of an American diplomat and the kidnapping of his wife, whose brother is
linked to the Iraq oil-for-food scandal.
MARY, MARY, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) The F.B.I. agent Alex
Cross tracks a Hollywood killer who announces the crimes via e-mail.
DEATH DANCE, by Linda Fairstein. (Scribner, $26.) Alexandra Cooper, a
Manhattan assistant district attorney, investigates the disappearance of a ballerina.
EVERY BREATH YOU TAKE, by Judith McNaught. (Ballantine, $25.95.) When the
grandson of a Chicago philanthropist disappears, suspicion falls on the wrong man.
“S” IS FOR SILENCE, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/Putnam, $26.95.) Kinsey
Millhone searches for a woman who disappeared 34 years ago.
THE CAT WHO DROPPED A BOMBSHELL, by Lilian Jackson Braun. (Putnam,
$23.95.) The columnist Jim Qwilleran and his cats investigate the mysterious death
of a wealthy couple.
AT FIRST SIGHT, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $24.95.) The young couple from
"True Believer," who are now expecting a child, receive a disturbing message.
TURNING ANGEL, by Greg Iles. (Scribner, $25.95.) To defend a friend wrongly
accused of murder, a Mississippi lawyer must investigate the secret lives of local
prep school students.
THE LAST TEMPLAR, by Raymond Khoury. (Dutton, $24.95.) A coding device
stolen from an exhibit of Vatican artifacts may hold clues to the medieval Knights
Templar's long-lost treasure — and their secrets.
ON THE RUN, by Iris Johansen. (Bantam, $26.) A little girl and her mother, a gifted
horse trainer who once worked for the C.I.A., are targeted by a Middle Eastern
magnate.
JUST REWARDS, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) Concluding
the story of the Harte family and its financial empire, told through four generations
of women.
CHRIST THE LORD: OUT OF EGYPT, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $25.95.) What
happened in Bethlehem; a story narrated by a 7-year-old who discovers that he is
the Prince of Peace.
February 5, 2006
Non-Fiction
FOR LACI, by Sharon Rocha. (Crown, $25.95.) Laci Peterson's mother recalls her
daughter and describes her killer's trial.
MARLEY & ME, by John Grogan. (Morrow, $21.95.) A newspaper columnist and
his wife learn some life lessons from their neurotic dog.
THE WORLD IS FLAT, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.)
A columnist for The New York Times analyzes 21st-century economics and foreign
policy and presents an overview of globalization trends.
MY FRIEND LEONARD, by James Frey. (Riverhead, $24.95.) The author of "A
Million Little Pieces" remembers a helpful mobster friend.
NIGHT, by Elie Wiesel. (Hill & Wang, $19.95.) A new translation of an account of
the horrors of Auschwitz and Buchenwald, first published in English in 1960.
THE YEAR OF MAGICAL THINKING, by Joan Didion. (Knopf, $23.95.) The
author's attempts to come to terms with the death of her husband and the grave
illness of their only daughter.
FREAKONOMICS, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $25.95.)
A maverick scholar applies economic thinking to everything from sumo wrestlers
who cheat to legalized abortion and the falling crime rate.
TEACHER MAN, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $26.) The author of "Angela's
Ashes" remembers his years teaching high school English in New York City.
A MILLION LITTLE PIECES, by James Frey. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $22.95.)
Both author and publisher acknowledge that this memoir contains numerous
fabrications.
TEAM OF RIVALS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) The
political genius of Abraham Lincoln, revealed in his relationship with his cabinet,
from the author of "No Ordinary Time."
MONEY SECRETS, by Dave Barry. (Crown, $24.95.) The humorist looks at
personal finance.
OUR ENDANGERED VALUES, by Jimmy Carter. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) The
former president warns against blurring politics and fundamentalist religion.
STATE OF WAR, by James Risen. (Free Press, $26.) The secret history of the
C.I.A. and the Bush administration.
BLINK, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The author of "The Tipping
Point" explores the importance of hunch and instinct to the workings of the mind.
